Not only did he talk, but he had a voice that kind of came out through his nose and it

Non-stop all the time.

And then it was, talk, talk, talk, talk, talk, again, talk, talk, talk, talk.
I couldn't stand it.
It was so aggravating.
Finally, one day I got super annoyed.
We were sitting on the ground during reading time and I was just trying to read and he kept

I'd had enough and I finally looked at him and I said, would you just shut your mouth?
Only instead of saying it quietly because I was so mad, it came out way too loud.
So loud that everyone in the classroom heard me say it, including the teacher.

The teacher Mrs. Talley was her name.

I was the one that got sent to the principal's office, even though it was Giannath and
then been talking.

You see, there was a man that used to come over to our house sometimes.
He was older than my dad but not by much.
My dad called him Captain.
The captain had been in the Navy but he didn't drive ships.
He was a pilot in the Navy.
He flew planes and during the Vietnam War, his plane was shot down and he parachuted to
the ground but when he landed, he was surrounded by the enemy and they captured him and put
him into a prisoner of war camp and it was an awful place.
There was horrible food and they didn't get much of it and the water made them sick
and they lived in barren rooms called prison cells and it was hot and it was miserable.
And the prisoners were treated horribly by the guards in the prison.
They were beaten and they were starved and they were given no freedom to do anything.
The only good thing that the prisoners had is that they were not alone.
There were other prisoners there, mostly other pilots that had been shot down and most
of the time they lived with each other in these tiny prison cells.
I only knew about all this because my dad had told me what had happened to the captain.
Well, after I got in trouble at school for getting annoyed at Jonathan who talked all the time
and I yelled at him, my dad invited the captain over to my house and my dad said that the captain
wanted to tell me something and when we sat down after dinner, the captain looked at me
and started to talk.
And when the captain talked, everybody listened.
The captain spoke slowly and clearly and you could tell that he meant every word he said.
And this is what he told me that night. He said, Jake, I know you got into some trouble at school.
I know you got annoyed with another kid and yelled at him during class.
Now, I want to tell you something.
When I was a fighter pilot, I was shot down and got captured by the enemy.
I was put into a prison camp and it was a horrible place and in that prison we had cellmates.
Those were the other prisoners that we lived with and the rooms were small and we were hungry
and we were sick and we were tired and we were miserable.
And in that terrible situation, it would be very, very easy for me to get annoyed with my cellmates.
In fact, we all could have gotten annoyed with each other.
Maybe my cellmate snored or maybe he coughed all day and all night or maybe he
cracked his knuckles all the time or picked his nose or scratched his feet in a gross way that made

Six years. That is a long, long, long time to be in prison and that is a long, long,
long time to be annoyed. And in that prison, we didn't have many other choices for friends.
It was just us and our cellmates. That's it.
So we came up with a rule and the rule was that if someone annoyed us, it wasn't their fault.
But it was our fault. It was our fault if we let their snoring bother us.
If my roommate snored, it was my fault. If I let that bother me, it was my fault. If I got
aggravated at the way my cellmate scratched his feet. It was my fault. If I couldn't stand the way
that my cellmate coughed or talked or cracked his knuckles. It was my fault. That was the rule.
We couldn't allow ourselves to get annoyed. Being annoyed would have made that prison much,
much worse than it already was and we couldn't have that and we didn't have that.
Ever. So, Jake, if you let someone annoy you, you're allowing something that shouldn't control
you to control you. You're letting it get inside your head. And I know you're young, but that's
no excuse. You can't do that. You have to learn to ignore the little things that annoy you. I promise
you that there are enough things in life that can go wrong, big things, important things that
you'll have to worry about. So, don't let these little things bother you. Just accept them.
And shake them off. Think about something else. And don't focus on little things that annoy you,

And I said to the captain, yes, sir, and I meant it. I couldn't believe what the captain had been

When you act like things don't bother you, eventually they don't. So be strong and don't let
